commit_message:
Support batching up commands

When you have around 60 baremetal nodes attached to a single switch, it
takes a long time to execute all those commands. This gets worse when
you limit the number of concurrent ssh connections.

Here we look to batch up commands to send to the switch together using a
single connection. The results of each port's commands are returned when
available.

This is implemented using etcd as a queueing system. Commands are added
to an input key, then a worker thread processes the available commands
for a particular switch device. We pull off the queue using the version
at which the keys were added, giving a FIFO style queue. The result of
each command set are added to an output key, which the original request
thread is watching. Distributed locks are used to serialise the
processing of commands for each switch device.

Various neat etcd features are used here to alleviate some of the issues
of distributed task coordination, including transactions, leases,
watches, historical key/value tracking, etc.

Co-Authored-By: Mark Goddard <mark@stackhpc.com>

Change-Id: I8c458bbc94df5630cfede5434bcdbe527988059c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-generic-switch refs/changes/83/743283/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2020 StackHPC # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json import etcd3gw import eventlet from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_utils import netutils from oslo_utils import uuidutils import tenacity LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class SwitchBatch(object): EXEC_LOCK = "/ngs/batch/%s/execute_lock" INPUT_PREFIX = "/ngs/batch/%s/input/" INPUT_ITEM_KEY = "/ngs/batch/%s/input/%s" RESULT_ITEM_KEY = "/ngs/batch/%s/output/%s" def __init__(self, switch_name, etcd_url, etcd_client=None): self.switch_name = switch_name self.client = etcd_client if self.client is None: parsed_url = netutils.urlsplit(etcd_url) host = parsed_url.hostname port = parsed_url.port # TODO(johngarbutt): support certs protocol = 'https' if parsed_url.scheme.endswith( 'https') else 'http' timeout = 30 self.client = etcd3gw.client( host=host, port=port, protocol=protocol, timeout=timeout) def do_batch(self, cmd_set, get_connection, do_batch, save_config): # request that the cmd_set by executed watch_info = self._add_batch(cmd_set) def do_work(): LOG.debug("starting to do work") try: self._execute_pending_batches( get_connection, do_batch, save_config) except Exception as e: LOG.error("failed to run execute batch: %s", e, exec_info=True) raise # Sleep to let possible other work to batch together eventlet.sleep(0.1) # Run all pending tasks, which might be a no op # if pending tasks already ran eventlet.spawn_n(do_work) # Wait for our result key # as the result might be done before the above task starts output = self._wait_for_result(*watch_info) LOG.debug("Got batch result: %s", output) return output def _add_batch(self, cmds): """Clients add batch, given key to wait on for completion.""" # TODO(johngarbutt) update this so we preserve insertion order uuid = uuidutils.generate_uuid() result_key = self.RESULT_ITEM_KEY % (self.switch_name, uuid) input_key = self.INPUT_ITEM_KEY % (self.switch_name, uuid) # Start waiting on the key we expect to be created # Do this before anyone knows to create it, to avoid racing result_events, watch_cancel = self.client.watch(result_key) # TODO(johngarbutt) add a lease so this times out? event = { "uuid": uuid, "input_key": input_key, "result_key": result_key, "cmds": cmds, } value = json.dumps(event).encode("utf-8") success = self.client.create(input_key, value) if not success: raise Exception("failed to add batch to key: %s", input_key) LOG.debug("written input key %s", input_key) return result_key, result_events, watch_cancel def _execute_pending_batches(self, get_connection, do_batch, save_config): """Execute all batches currently registered. Typically called by every caller of add_batch. Often a noop if all batches are already executed. """ input_prefix = self.INPUT_PREFIX % self.switch_name batches = self.client.get_prefix(input_prefix) if not batches: LOG.debug("Skipped execution for %s", self.switch_name) return LOG.debug("Getting lock to execute %d batches", len(batches)) lock_ttl_seconds = 300 lock_name = self.EXEC_LOCK % self.switch_name lock = self.client.lock(lock_name, lock_ttl_seconds) @tenacity.retry( # Log a message after each failed attempt. after=tenacity.after_log(LOG, logging.DEBUG), # Retry if we haven't got the lock yet retry=tenacity.retry_if_result(lambda x: x is False), # Stop after the configured timeout. stop=tenacity.stop_after_delay(400), # Wait for the configured interval between attempts. wait=tenacity.wait_fixed(2), ) def _acquire_lock_with_retry(): lock_acquired = lock.acquire() if lock_acquired: return True # Stop waiting for the lock if there is nothing to do work = self.client.get_prefix(input_prefix) if not work: return None # Trigger a retry return False # Be sure we got the lock got_lock = _acquire_lock_with_retry() if not got_lock or not lock.is_acquired(): raise Exception("unable to get lock: %s", lock_name) # be sure to drop the lock when we are done results = {} with lock: LOG.debug("got lock %s", lock_name) # Fetch fresh list now we have the lock # and order the list so we execute in order added batches = self.client.get_prefix(input_prefix, sort_order="ascend", sort_target="create") if not batches: LOG.debug("No batches to execute %s", self.switch_name) return LOG.debug("Starting to execute %d batches", len(batches)) # TODO(johngarbutt) seem to have two threads getting here!! keys = [metadata["key"] for value, metadata in batches] LOG.debug("Starting to execute keys: %s", keys) lock.refresh() with get_connection() as connection: connection.enable() lock.refresh() # Try to apply all the batches # and save all the results all_cmds = [] for value, metadata in batches: batch = json.loads(value.decode('utf-8')) input_key = metadata["key"] all_cmds += batch['cmds'] # LOG.debug("executing: %s %s", batch, metadata) results[input_key] = { 'result': "TODO", 'input_key': input_key, 'result_key': batch['result_key'], } # LOG.debug("got result: %s", results[input_key]) # lock.refresh() LOG.debug("doing all batches: %s", all_cmds) result = do_batch(connection, all_cmds) LOG.debug("got result: %s", result) # Save the changes we made # TODO(johngarbutt) maybe undo failed configs first? LOG.debug("Start save config") save_config(connection) LOG.debug("Finish save config") lock.refresh() LOG.debug("lock refreshed") # Now we have saved the config, # tell the waiting threads we are done LOG.debug("write results to etcd") for input_key, result_dict in results.items(): # TODO(johngarbutt) create this with a lease # so auto delete if no one gets the result? success = self.client.create( result_dict['result_key'], json.dumps(result_dict['result']).encode('utf-8')) if not success: # TODO(johngarbutt) should we fail to delete the key at # this point? LOG.error("failed to report batch result for: %s", batch) else: LOG.debug("reported result: %s", input_key) # Stop the next lock holder thinking they need # to do this again delete_success = self.client.delete(input_key) if not delete_success: LOG.error("unable to delete input key: %s", input_key) else: LOG.debug("deleted input key: %s", input_key) lock.refresh() LOG.debug("Finished executing keys: %s", keys) LOG.debug("end of lock %s", lock_name) def _get_result(self, result_key): LOG.debug("fetching key %s", result_key) # TODO(johngarbutt) need to look in the event! results = self.client.get(result_key, metadata=True) if len(results) != 1: LOG.error("Failed to fetch result for %s", result_key) raise Exception("can't find result: %s", result_key) raw = results[0][0] batch_result = json.loads(raw.encode('utf-8')) LOG.debug("deleting key, now we have result: %s", result_key) is_deleted = self.client.delete(result_key) if not is_deleted: LOG.error("Unable to delete key %s", result_key) return batch_result def _wait_for_result(self, result_key, result_events, watch_cancel): """Blocks until result is received""" # TODO(johngarbutt) need to timeout this? for event in result_events: LOG.debug("Got event: %s", event) # TODO(johngarbutt): check this is the event we wanted! watch_cancel() return self._get_result(result_key)

subject: Apply rate limit for journald in AIO builds
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-08-21 15:41:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/c9fa20101325fa5c82f609876468f0c9cdfdc924', 'message': 'Apply rate limit for journald in AIO builds

At the moment we experience DISK_FULL issue in CI for upgrade
jobs on Rocky. This happens as our log files are more then
available per-job limit, which is capped at 5Gb. In order
to see what fills up the diskspace and reduce overall disk consumption,
we apply rate limiting and define maximum size of files as well as
total diskspace that can be consumed by logs not to exceed that limit.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts/+/892151
Change-Id: I960a4377f6cfc6977a4d0df0e53744cdfb539b1e

commit_message:
Apply rate limit for journald in AIO builds

At the moment we experience DISK_FULL issue in CI for upgrade
jobs on Rocky. This happens as our log files are more then
available per-job limit, which is capped at 5Gb. In order
to see what fills up the diskspace and reduce overall disk consumption,
we apply rate limiting and define maximum size of files as well as
total diskspace that can be consumed by logs not to exceed that limit.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts/+/892151
Change-Id: I960a4377f6cfc6977a4d0df0e53744cdfb539b1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/55/892155/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # systemd-journald limitations openstack_hosts_journald_config: RateLimitIntervalSec: 60 RateLimitBurst: 600 SystemMaxUse: 4G RuntimeMaxUse: 2G SystemMaxFileSize: 100M RuntimeMaxFileSize: 100M

commit_message:
Add support for Rocky Linux

* Added support for Rocky Linux in the amphora-agent
* Amphora images for Rocky can be built when setting
  OCTAVIA_AMP_BASE_OS="rocky"
* Fixed the devstack plugin for Rocky Linux hosts

Change-Id: I41f7e2341332b9cb74b4a59fedb6eed1af3c8062

This job does not publish the image. required-projects: - openstack/diskimage-builder vars: amphora_os: rocky amphora_os_release: 9 - job:

commit_message:
Replace base64.encodestring with base64.encodebytes

Base64.encodestring has been deprecated since 3.1 and removed
in python 3.9,Replace it with base64.encodebytes from python3.1[1].

[1]https://docs.python.org/3.9/library/base64.html?highlight=deprecated#base64.encodebytes

Change-Id: I159bf1db5e74c5c5e604d4f11660c2a0be916ae0

commit_message:
[Pure Storage] Fix missing pod causing driver failure

If a Pure replication pod is deleted and the driver is
subsequently restarted, this can cause the driver to fail.

This patch resolves that issue.

commit_message:
Use re2 compatible regexes in branch matchers

Python regexes are deprecated in Zuul, so update the use of regexes
in branch matchers with re2-compatible syntax.
The commit also removes matches for branches that are EOL - all
branches until stable/rocky (including).

Change-Id: I43c696ef2029cbf351f902b293df05f296dbb2a2

commit_message:
Use re2 compatible regexes in branch matchers

Python regexes are deprecated in Zuul, so update the use of regexes
in branch matchers with re2-compatible syntax.
The commit also removes matches for branches that are EOL - all
branches until stable/rocky (including).

Change-Id: I461f00415d67ba5af8ad2387fc2d5dd224a733db

commit_message:
Ensure boolean values at horizon::wsgi::apache

We already added these validations to the horizon class, but having
the same in the underlying implementation allows us to ensure
the supported types are passed down.

Change-Id: I591f7ee273030f16184d8b53768b3594efc22e35

commit_message:
Fix manage.py to use python3

Looks like we still have some py2 legacy sheebang that we need fixing.

Backport note:
This backport contains If403d134122c4b55e653057a9eb6c469bc66b39e which
fixed the issue with virtualenv.

commit_message:
Implement Ensure Shares in the CephFS driver

This allows switching between NFS protocol helpers
that the driver currently supports and avoids
unnecessary ensuring of driver resources on restarts
unless a small set of config opts are toggled.

Use of either NFS protocol helper in the driver
will trigger access rules to be reapplied when
ensuring shares.

Implements: bp use-cephadm-nfs-ganesha
Partial-Bug: #2035137
Change-Id: I93c4e8616a1cfb5ab713b420aff69464969f28d5
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit ee8af90109cc41d1c22f2e0cd1718f7cfd2fdfe7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/34/895034/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | The CephFS backend driver now supports a bulk share recovery mechanism (``ensure_shares``). At startup time, a combination of driver configuration options will determine if the driver must re-evaluate export paths of previously created shares. If these configuration options do not change, service startup will skip through this recovery stage. - | The CephFS backend driver will also reapply access rules when performing a recovery of pre-existing shares. upgrade: - | A new configuration option called ``cephfs_ensure_all_shares_salt`` has been introduced to assist cloud administrtrators that would like the CephFS driver to reconcile export paths of existing shares during service startup.

subject: [xena] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-08-17 12:56:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-aodh/commit/ed6e130fea26cf90219db032c36d1cd957599874', 'message': "[xena] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

commit_message:
[xena] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/828
Closes-Bug: #2028683

Change-Id: Ieb16b5600c7bf66931083fbedbd1402dcab26bfe

commit_message:
Add preferred info to ceph nfs export locations

Change the Ceph NFS helpers to update the export locations
preferred field based on the configuration. The preferred export
location will always relate to the Ceph ADM deployed Ganesha
cluster.

Partial-Bug: #2035137
Change-Id: I9b05a6444b8ac98f79f297fec9c74a45ef11429d
(cherry picked from commit 3eb34c3ce7feaf51012c3338a03882b0d103138a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/68/895368/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | It is now possible to configure `cephfs_ganesha_export_ips` (or alternatively, `cephfs_ganesha_server_ip`) alongside `cephfs_nfs_cluster_id`. Setting these options will allow the CephFS driver to report additional export paths. These additional export paths will have the "preferred" metadata key set to False. The export paths pertaining to the NFS service host discovered by the driver will have the "preferred" metadata key set to True. It is expected that administrators will configure additional IP addresses when preparing to migrate from a standalone NFS-Ganesha service to a NFS service cluster setup facilitated by the Ceph orchestration service. Eventually, when the migration has completed, these configuration options can be removed and the corresponding share export path records will be dropped from Manila. Note that the CephFS driver will not create or manipulate access rules within the NFS service configured via `cephfs_ganesha_export_ips` or `cephfs_ganesha_server_ip`. upgrades: - | In order to assist the user experience when migrating from a standalone CephFS NFS (NFS-Ganesha) service to an NFS service created with the Ceph Orchestrator, the CephFS driver allows configuring `cephfs_ganesha_export_ips` (or alternatively, `cephfs_ganesha_server_ip`) alongside `cephfs_nfs_cluster_id`.

subject: Pure: Report SAM-2 addressing mode for LUNs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-02-21 19:23:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/02be1aa0be65294dbc1097a31b4b9706a3ef64e6', 'message': "Pure: Report SAM-2 addressing mode for LUNs

Pure iSCSI and FC drivers use SCSI SAM-2 addressing mode, which means
that LUNs < 256 use peripheral mode (unmodified values) and LUNs >= 256
use flat mode (2 higher bits of the MSB must be 01b).

This is not the standard behavior of os-brick, which defaults to
SAM/transparent mode.

In this patch the Pure storage driver reports it's addressing mode so
that LUNs with value greater than 255 can be connected by os-brick.

commit_message:
Pure: Report SAM-2 addressing mode for LUNs

Pure iSCSI and FC drivers use SCSI SAM-2 addressing mode, which means
that LUNs < 256 use peripheral mode (unmodified values) and LUNs >= 256
use flat mode (2 higher bits of the MSB must be 01b).

This is not the standard behavior of os-brick, which defaults to
SAM/transparent mode.

In this patch the Pure storage driver reports it's addressing mode so
that LUNs with value greater than 255 can be connected by os-brick.

Depends-On: If32d054e8f944f162bdc8700d842134a80049877
Closes-Bug: #2006960
Change-Id: I4abfb6de58340c5ea70e7a796326f5d2089c80eb

commit_message:
Support reapplying rules during ensuring

This is an internal change in the share manager's
"ensure_driver_resources" method, and isn't invoked
by any code path yet. The idea is to allow drivers
to opt into running "update_access" on shares that
they are ensuring.

Only drivers that implement "ensure_shares" can
take advantage of this feature.

Change-Id: Ieb7b0dedd98dc02b593078d08d4c0bdf4a1af2bf
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 389a2ea1e5f1e96386128af1a90dbbb9f95811f1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/33/895033/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update ptgbot to python3.11 and Bookworm

We update python testing from python3.8 to python3.11 to match the
deployment setup in the Docker image. We then update the docker image
from python3.9 + bullseye to python3.11 + bookworm. This is future
proofing, but also OpenDev would like to clean up old docker container
image builds for bullseye and older python.

Change-Id: Ifbb7dcf2bf5f0b7ea4f53e26dd4bf4911c9b8d37

commit_message:
Use netcat-openbsd on debian bookworm

The 'netcat' package is no longer installable directly.

    Package netcat is a virtual package provided by:
      netcat-openbsd 1.219-1
      netcat-traditional 1.10-47
    You should explicitly select one to install.
    E: Package 'netcat' has no installation candidate

Change-Id: I4d2cd14abfb0f9c7d02438684af010965d940a4b

commit_message:
Remove new line from ssh-key

This change removes the newline \n character from the ssh-key. This
prevents the line being duplicated during each execution of the
tripleo_create_admin role.

Signed-off-by: Brendan Shephard <bshephar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I9615c4d1a006c7ee87745cb31f14ca385659b5a7
Resolves: rhbz#2238601

commit_message:
[train] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/832
Closes-Bug: #2028683

Change-Id: I7d78b3c483230878676b572aa803d15a4f7a23f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceilometer refs/changes/90/891990/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Do not install qemu package on debian derived OS

This is a dummy package with almost no content and no dependancies.
It does not exist on debian 12.

commit_message:
[xena] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/828
Closes-Bug: #2028683

Change-Id: I2f13374aaad2c66dda426ad7760d1b6b28b9637a

[train] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available

commit_message:
[Pure Storage] Uniform Sync Replication disconnect

When a sync replicated volume is disconnected, the host connection
on the secondary array is not correctly removed.

This patch resolves that by ensuring the remote host connections
are also removed before the final disconnection of the volume from
the host.

Closes-Bug: #2029005
Change-Id: If1c08e918710b809ec62612e77740131914e2233
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/22/890022/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Dell Powerflex: Add new VOLUME_ALREADY_MAPPED_ERROR

Dell Powerflex 4.x changed the error code of VOLUME_ALREADY_MAPPED_ERROR
to 4037. This patch adds that error code.

Closes-Bug: #201374
Change-Id: Ieba81765f1b68f0b07d6cf1545bd6132df16e831

commit_message:
[victoria] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/830
Closes-Bug: #2028683

Change-Id: I34bb4e239fe999d3d54040583db0a98ef4c1a7ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-glance refs/changes/87/891887/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[2023.1] Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/825
Closes-Bug: #2028683

Change-Id: I9f195752974b350e5cd4f1577d6225e0251f158d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-glance refs/changes/34/891534/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sent = relation_get(rid=rid, unit=local_unit()) legacy_keys = ['certificate_name', 'common_name'] is_legacy_request = set(sent).intersection(legacy_keys) # Note: Bug#2028683 - data may not be available if the certificates # relation hasn't been populated by the providing charm. If no 'ca' # in the data then don't attempt the bundle at all. if data.get('ca'): if data.get(raw_certs_key): bundles.append({ 'ca': data['ca'], 'chain': data.get('chain'), 'certs': json.loads(data[raw_certs_key]) }) elif is_legacy_request: bundles.append({ 'ca': data['ca'], 'chain': data.get('chain'), 'certs': { sent['common_name']: { 'cert': data.get(local_name + '.server.cert'), 'key': data.get(local_name + '.server.key') } } })
deleted_lines: if data.get(raw_certs_key): bundles.append({ 'ca': data['ca'], 'chain': data.get('chain'), 'certs': json.loads(data[raw_certs_key])})

subject: WiP Watcher should enforce the Nova policies
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-15 10:47:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/watcher-specs/commit/1abeb07070ff1a803783d2bad6d82a5f4a233d13', 'message': 'WiP Watcher should respect the Nova policies

In the current implementation of watcher, we are bypassing the
rules of the nova scheduler.This may result in failure or even worse,
the violation of the nova policies (affinity rules, capacity, ...).
This is clearly not sustainable, watcher strategies have to be conform to
the administrators specifications.

Change-Id: I6b7572dfd7b62eb3cad9a2e4c128af3545b00883
blueprint: nova-policies

commit_message:
WiP Watcher should enforce the Nova policies

In the current implementation of watcher, we are bypassing the
rules of the nova scheduler.This may result in failure or even worse,
the violation of the nova policies (affinity rules, capacity, ...).
This is clearly not sustainable, watcher strategies have to be conform to
the administrators specifications.

Co-Authored-By: Jean-Emile DARTOIS <jean-emile.dartois@b-com.com>
Co-Authored-By: Susanne Balle <sleipnir012@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I6b7572dfd7b62eb3cad9a2e4c128af3545b00883
blueprint: nova-policies
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher-specs refs/changes/73/329873/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= WiP Respect the Nova policies ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/nova-policies This spec reconsider (or goes beyond) the `select-destinations-filter`_ blueprint. In the current implementation of watcher, we are bypassing the rules of the nova scheduler. This may result in failure or even worse, the violation of the nova policies (affinity rules, capacity, ...). This is clearly not sustainable, watcher strategies have to be conform to the administrators specifications. Problem description =================== The Filter Scheduler uses the 'select_destinations' method to decide where to create or move an instance across the cloud compute infrastructure. It is used for placement of a new instance as well as migration of an existing instance. In the `select-destinations-filter`_ blueprint, we thought that we could reuse this feature in Watcher to verify that the migration proposed by the watcher strategies didn't break the Nova policies but this solution leads to several problems. Before diving into the problems, let's make clear the behaviour of the 'select_destinations' method. In order to invoke the 'select_destinations' method, we have to first retrieve the RequestSpec object `request-spec-object`_ of the instance that we want to migrate. Then, we can specify in the RequestSpec the requested destination. We can only specify one Destination at a time nova/scheduler/host_manager.py. Finally, we can invoke the 'select_destinations' method with the modified RequestSpec as parameter. If the requested destination satisfies the nova policies, the requested destination is returned, otherwise the NoValidHost exception is raised. Nova throws this error also when it fails to find the appropriate target host for an instance The first problem is that the 'select_destinations' method is an internal API and It is well known that this is not a good practice to invoke RPC API directly, especially between two components that do not belong to the same Openstack project. However, Jay Pipes has recently added the blueprint `scheduler-rest-api-select-destinations`_ which aims at exposing the 'select_destinations' as a RESTFul API. In the next sentences, we are assuming that we can call 'select_destinations' method from Watcher through this RESTFul API. The second problem is the tracking of the resources. In fact, each time the 'select_destinations' method has validated a host, the nova scheduler is virtually consuming the resources of the instance on the selected host until the information is updated per compute node(nova/scheduler/host_manager.py:182) This is not a problem for Nova because this is only one step in a wider workflow. In fact, each time the 'select_destinations' method is called, the Nova Scheduler will return the selected host and then, it will try to start the instance on it, as soon as possible. In Watcher this is not the case. The strategy developer can create a large scope of VM placement algorithms thanks to his pluggable architecture (they can for example use exact approaches and Heuristics or Meta-heuristics). It can be useful in the decision making (Watcher strategy)to check the configuration validity or test an optimization algorithm before applying it to the system. In fact, some strategies may generate several solutions and use an objective function to assess the efficiency of each potential solution. In other words, the Watcher strategies may try a high number of combinations of virtual machine migrations in order to reach the audit goals (minimize energy consumption, load balacing, etc). Therefore, in a Watcher strategy it makes sense to evaluate a migration action but never execute this action. So, if we invoke the 'select_destinations' method in the Watcher strategies, the nova scheduler will quickly (depending of the numbers of available hosts) raise the NoValidHost exception and may refuse some migration even if it makes sense to temporarily violate some constraint in order to achieve a given optimization goal. We performed some benchmark in order to evaluate if the Nova-Scheduler can handle a high number of requests from the Watcher strategies. The results show that It takes in average 49 ms to validate 10 destinations and the time consumed by the select_destinations to reply is linearly related to the number of destinations. So, this is clearly not sustainable. You can see below a chart: .. image:: ../../../doc/source/images/caching_scheduler_performances.svg :width: 140% We performed the experiments on two dedicated Ubuntu 14.04 server with 24 cores, 125 GB RAM and a solid state disk. All of the OpenStack services were running on one server except the Nova-compute and Ceilometer. The scheduler driver is configured with the `CachingScheduler`_ and the 'select_destination' is exposed through a RESTFul API. The fourth problem is that Watcher is blind (it has no way to integrate the Nova constraints in its strategies). We can only try a new placement for an instance and then see if the Nova-scheduler agrees. If this instance has an affinity constraint, we can try many combinations and never find a viable solution. It would be much more efficient for the Watcher strategies to fetch a snapshot of the nova policies and try the combinations internally. The last problem is that we can't use the of 'select_destinations' to validate instances with an affinity group. It's seem that the soft-affinity-for-server-group blueprint tackle this problem. We should take a look to Do we need to see an affinity group has a monolithic instance ? Use Cases ---------- As a strategy developer, I want to have the Nova policies of the instances (scheduler hints) to make sure that the destination host that I'm providing are conform to the administrators specifications. As an administrator trying to optimize his infrastructure, I would like to use the Nova Scheduler to validate/check the Watcher Audit before applying it to the system. Project Priority ----------------- Proposed change =============== This specification suggests to retrieve a snapshot of the instances policies. In this way, it will be possible to have holistic approach to determine the optimal cloud datacenter configuration, while meeting the tenants SLAs. .. image:: ../../../doc/source/images/nova_watcher.svg :width: 140% This specification suggests to retrieve a snapshot of the instances policies. In this way, it will be possible to have holistic approach to determine the optimal cloud datacenter configuration, while meeting the tenants SLAs. .. image:: ../../../doc/source/images/nova_watcher.svg :width: 140% As shown in the diagram above, the `Watcher Decision Engine`_ service should fetch the Nova policies in order to be aware of the instance placement constraints. The selected strategy is able then to compute the needed actions for the solution in order to achieve its goals without violating the Nova constraints. Finally, the flow of actions is sent to the Watcher Applier which submits each migration action to Nova for validation. It would be much better to send the ActionPlan compared to only validate the action atomically. The cloud configuration may change over time in the same way as the workloads of the instances. So, the validity of the proposed actions are subject to a race condition. As a result, the validated actions can be invalidated 1s later. For example, the selected computes could no longer be accepting new instances because they have reached their maximum capacity meanwhile. This is the reason why, we will let the Nova-Scheduler confirm that the computed actions in the Audit are still complying with the Nova constraints. If later on, the audit is stale, we can launch a new audit. Watcher wants to incrementally improve the system when there is a possible time window, sometime this is not possible due to high demand. However, when an error occurs or when an action become stale at one of the scheduled action, we can retry later or use a pre-computed alternative path. Considering the Action Plan belonging to a directed acyclic graph, the Watcher Applier can execute a sub-graph which is capable to react to the error as gracefully as possible. We could for example use the Nova-Scheduler to pro-actively select a pre-computed alternative path. However, solving this problem is not in the scope of this spec. In the same way, we will also need the `automatic-triggering-audit`_ blueprint which aims to reduce the time between the audit and his application (Watcher will automatically apply the Audit). It will be also be usefull to have the `specify-multiple-live-migrate-hosts`_ blueprint implemented to directly propose to Nova-Scheduler several options. The workflow engine code in watcher/applier/workflow_engine/default.py will need to be changed. Specifically, the execute method will be amended to pro-actively check the validity of the Audit. The code of the migration action (watcher/applier/actions/migration.py#precondition) will be amended to validate the migration of the instance by calling the select_destinations method. The BaseStrategy class watcher/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/base.py will be amended to add the get_policies method. We should adapt all existing strategies so that they take into account the Nova constraints. We shoud provide a helper for the strategies developer to query the nova policies. Elements that should be discussed with the Nova team: This spec will need that the 'select_destinations' method to be exposed as a RESTFul API. This spec will also need that the RequestSpec object to be exposed as a RESTFul API. We could be also nice to be able to subscribe Nova / Novaclient / openstackclient may also have to be modified. Do we need to provide our own driver of Nova-Scheduler ? It may have some performances issues with the collection of the policies. We could re-use the approach proposed by `cluster-model-objects-wrapper`_ blueprint but for providing a collector that is responsible for maintaining the nova policies in a memory cache.if we can't modify the nova implementation, we could provide some plugins capable of exposing the RequestSpec object and the select_destinations method. Alternatives ------------ An alternative approach would be to rely on a dedicated component in Openstack in charge of exposing the policies. Today, Congress seems to be the most relevant Openstack project for this kind of feature. It would be less intrusive if Nova could publish some events on the bus each time a new policy/constraint is added to Nova. This "event sourcing" approach would enable other components (such as Watcher or Congress) to subscribe to these events and use them to trigger other events or build their own structural model for their own needs. It would also enable the developers to improve their optimization strategies by rebuilding Nova context from the event store. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Developer impact Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ Elements that should be discussed with the Nova team: WIP This spec will need that the 'select_destinations' method to be exposed as a RESTFul API. Nova / Novaclient / openstackclient may also have to be modified. Do we need to provide our own driver of the Nova-Scheduler ? Testing ======= * Update unit tests in the `Watcher Decision Engine`_ Documentation Impact ==================== * Update the page named "*Build a new optimization strategy*" explaining how to use the nova policies. References ========== .. _select-destinations-filter: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/select-destinations-filter .. _request-spec-object: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/request-spec-object .. _scheduler-rest-api-select-destinations: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/scheduler-rest-api-select-destinations .. _CachingScheduler: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Nova/CachingScheduler .. _automatic-triggering-audit: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/automatic-triggering-audit .. _specify-multiple-live-migrate-hosts: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/specify-multiple-live-migrate-hosts .. _soft-affinity-for-server-group: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/soft-affinity-for-server-group .. _cluster-model-objects-wrapper: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/cluster-model-objects-wrapper .. _Watcher Decision Engine: https://factory.b-com.com/www/watcher/doc/watcher/architecture.html#watcher-decision-engine * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/check-destination-on-migrations * What is exaclty the scope of this blueprint ? * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/scheduler-separate-endgoal History =======

commit_message:
WIP db: Remove use of autocommit

WIP because I clearly haven't caught all of these yet. I wish I'd better
debugging techniques for figuring out when a transaction starts.

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ieb07ef7ddb50a88ffc3e1fdea4cc5f0acc45cb3f

commit_message:
debian: Remove kolla-ansible-debian-zun job

* When the Debian job got upgraded from Bullseye
  to Bookworm, the non-voting Zun job started failing.
* This is because Debian Bookworm doesn't support the
  required Docker 20 pinning.
* Until Zun gains support for newer dependencies this
  job will keep failing.

Change-Id: I1e1d9ea7c76d1b2f77b09b7948f138b88ef483d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/73/894573/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Debian Bookworm is not recommended as a host OS for Zun. It does not support a version of Docker with the deprecated option. Compatibility with Zun is not tested in CI.

commit_message:
Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/824
Closes-Bug: #2028683

Change-Id: I071037fbef7940e447d6aaefa61e38b988b37e66

This change moves the default return value for the Keystone api_version
 to 3.0 instead of 2.0. By this point in time, all supported OpenStack
  releases use Keystone API version 3.0 instead of 2.0.
 This was previously causing Nova templates to render with 2.0 in the

Closes-Bug: 1995778

'}]
commit_message:
Update default Keystone api_version

This change moves the default return value for the Keystone api_version
 to 3.0 instead of 2.0. By this point in time, all supported OpenStack
  releases use Keystone API version 3.0 instead of 2.0.
 This was previously causing Nova templates to render with 2.0 in the
 Keystone auth URL instead of 3.0, which caused auth failures.

Closes-Bug: 1995778
Change-Id: I6463a24fe4aaa654a58cff56720a55f0950db717

commit_message:
WIP: we want to track github releases easier

tools/check-github.py is start of something. All it does for now is
going through Github API and check for latest releases of components we
use.

Rate limited.

Change-Id: I9a8703861e174d8933e0a2cce63b076145eaa732
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/54/880154/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python3 # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import requests import sys github_projects = { "containernetworking/plugins", "etcd-io/etcd", "google/cadvisor", "google/mtail", "greenpau/ovn_exporter", "openstack-exporter/openstack-exporter", "prometheus/alertmanager", "prometheus/blackbox_exporter", "prometheus-community/elasticsearch_exporter", "prometheus/haproxy_exporter", "prometheus/memcached_exporter", "prometheus-msteams/prometheus-msteams", "prometheus/mysqld_exporter", "prometheus/node_exporter", "prometheus/prometheus" } for project in github_projects: response = requests.get(f"https://api.github.com/repos/{project}/" f"releases/latest", timeout=60) try: if "/" in response.json()["name"]: print("/") version = response.json()["name"].split("/")[0] else: version = response.json()["name"] print(f"{project} has {response.json()['name']} version") # rate limit probably except KeyError: print(response.json()["message"]) sys.exit(-1)

commit_message:
Ensure get_requests_for_local_unit doesn't fail on incomplete relation

This is a rebuild/make sync for charms to pickup the fix in charmhelpers to fix
any inadvertant accesses of ['ca'] in the relation data before it is available
from vault in the certificates relation.  Fix in charmhelpers is in [1].

[1] https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/824
Closes-Bug: #2028683

Change-Id: I3393fc63fa066b15f3e67c526ab3f2abe0ead028

commit_message:
Fixes for octavia-ingress-controller

- Add missing provider option, otherwise it hard codes to Octavia and
isn't usable.
- Enable security group management

Change-Id: I2322d7699df2e30decb06b34596d88b46ea255a2

commit_message:
Fix: volume request body for scheduler hints

Currently we pass 'OS-SCH-HNT:scheduler_hints' in the volume
request body in the volume JSON object. However, the scheduler
hints shouldn't be passed inside the volume JSON object and
passed separately in the body.

We need to do the same in SDK as done in cinderclient[1].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient/src/commit/f64df99134c95bb5f9e7d24deeb7869cd828aa4b/cinderclient/v3/volumes.py#L126-L127

Story: #2010868
Task: #48557
Change-Id: Ie09ae37dbdaeaa03f7ccef92d466fa6f2a58ad5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/93/890593/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _prepare_request_body(self, patch, prepend_key): body = self._body.dirty # Scheduler hints is external to the standard volume request # so pass it separately and not under the volume JSON object. scheduler_hints = None if 'OS-SCH-HNT:scheduler_hints' in body.keys(): scheduler_hints = body.pop('OS-SCH-HNT:scheduler_hints') if prepend_key and self.resource_key is not None: body = {self.resource_key: body} # If scheduler hints was passed in the request but the value is # None, it doesn't make a difference to include it. if scheduler_hints: body['OS-SCH-HNT:scheduler_hints'] = scheduler_hints return body
